title: R45107
content: The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans consists of 16 members appointed by key leaders in Congress. Two members serve as co-chairs, appointed within 14 days of the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. Up to $500,000 is authorized for expenses, disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans, established by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018, has authorized funds available for obligation until January 2, 2019. The committee may receive technical assistance from federal agencies and have legislative branch employees detailed to them. Members must comply with ethics rules, and the co-chairs can designate a staff director. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans, established by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018, is required to hold its first meeting by March 11, 2018. The committee must have at least nine members present for voting, with a lesser quorum of five members for hearings. They have the authority to hold hearings, subpoena witnesses and documents, and conduct at least five public hearings or meetings, including field hearings. Announcements for hearings must be made at least seven days in advance. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans must announce hearings at least seven days in advance. Each co-chair can select an equal number of witnesses. Witnesses must submit written testimony at least two days before appearing. The committee must vote on a report with findings, conclusions, recommendations, and legislative language by November 30, 2018. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans report must be approved by a majority of committee members. Proxy voting is not allowed. The Senate must vote on the recommended legislative language by the end of the 115th Congress. The report must be made public 24 hours before the vote. Members can submit additional views within two days after the report is approved. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans report must be approved by a majority of committee members. Proxy voting is not allowed. The report must be made public 24 hours before the vote. Members can submit additional views within two days after the report is approved. The final report, including all properly noticed views, must be submitted within 15 calendar days to the President, Vice President, Speaker of the House, and majority and minority leaders of the House and Senate. The full report, legislative language, and record of votes must be made available to the public promptly. Unique procedures are established for Senate consideration of legislative language from the committee. Legislation embodying recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans is introduced in the Senate by request of the majority leader. The bill is then jointly referred to the Senate Committee on Finance and the Committee on Health, Education, Labor. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans recommendations bill is jointly referred to the Senate Committee on Finance and the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions. The committees must act on the bill within a specified time frame to prevent delays or blockages. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans recommendations bill must be acted upon by the Senate committees within a specified time frame. The bill will be automatically discharged if not reported by the deadline, and it will then be placed on the Senate Calendar of Business for consideration. The Senate is directed to vote on a motion to proceed to the bill by the end of the 115th Congress. The majority leader or his designee may move to proceed to consider a joint committee bill related to the Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans. This bill may originate in the House of Representatives and be considered as a revenue measure. Senate action is required by the end of the 115th Congress. The Senate may proceed to consider a House-passed joint committee bill related to the Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans. If the leader does not move the bill within two session days, any Senator can call it up. Debate on the motion is limited to 10 hours, with an option to limit debate to less than 10 hours with a three-fifths vote. The act precludes certain motions in the Senate to postpone or reconsider the motion. The motion to proceed to a joint committee bill related to the Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans in the Senate requires a three-fifths vote (60 votes) to pass. This motion cannot be filibustered but still needs the same level of support as invoking cloture. The procedures in place shorten the time needed for cloture, eliminating the usual two session days wait and up to 30 additional hours of postcloture consideration before voting on the motion to proceed. The Senate motion to proceed to a joint committee bill on the Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans requires a three-fifths vote (60 votes) and can't be filibustered. All points of order against the motion are waived, and once pending, the bill is fully debatable and amendable. Expedited parliamentary procedures can be altered by either chamber as per Article I, Section 5 of the Constitution. The rules of the House or Senate can be changed at any time, including those set by statute. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 provides default parliamentary rules for Senate consideration of joint committee bills, which can be customized as needed. However, altering these procedures in the Senate may require unanimous consent due to the difficulty of overriding default terms. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 does not provide special procedures for House consideration of a Joint Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans. House floor consideration would be under a special rule agreed to by the House Committee on Rules. The act lacks provisions for resolving differences between the House and Senate or expediting consideration of a veto message from the President. Final vote on a bill may not be guaranteed. The Joint Select Committee on Solvency of Multiemployer Pension Plans is set to reach a final vote on a package for the President's consideration by December 31, 2018.
